awd_titl_txt: DMREF:  Collaborative Research:  Materials design of correlated metals as novel transparent conductors
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Transparent conductors are a critical component in many technologies affecting society, including solar cells, touch screens, flat panel displays, light emitting diodes and lasers. Finding materials that combine high electrical conductivity with excellent optical transparency in the visible spectrum has proved challenging: metals typically are good conductors but reflect rather than transmit visible light, while insulators like glass are highly transparent but do not carry an electrical current. The goal of this project is to pursue an unconventional paradigm, developed in previous work by members of the project team, to discover and develop new transparent conducting materials based on earth-abundant elements that exhibit substantially better performance and can be made with lower cost than the long-standing industry-standard indium-tin-oxide (ITO). Theoretical analysis combining mining of databases of materials property measurements and computations with predictive simulations of the structure and properties of candidate materials will be closely integrated with efforts in the laboratory to synthesize, characterize and optimize real materials. In the context of the Materials Genome Initiative coordinating efforts across the nation to accelerate the discovery, development and deployment of advanced materials, tools and techniques for integration of theory and experiment in materials design that are developed in the course of the project will be made available to the community to advance progress in broader materials design challenges. Breakthroughs in the development of transparent conductors will advance green technologies for energy generation, lighting, and passive building designs.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The conventional paradigm to combine the contradicted properties of transparency and high electrical conductivity is to heavily dope a wide band gap ? thus transparent ? semiconductor to increase its electrical conductivity. Rather than making a transparent semiconductor more conductive, the idea of the new paradigm is to make a metal optically transparent. This can be done by increasing the electron effective mass by correlation effects, which reduces the metal reflectivity in the visible range, in targeted systems for which interband transitions are above the visible range. The design space for the discovery of new transparent conductors spans a wide range of families, including correlated oxides, layered chalcogenides, pnictides, and intermetallic compounds. A hierarchical three-level search approach will be pursued. First, material candidates will be pre-screened in the available materials design space using simple-to-apply qualifier criteria, followed by high-throughput first-principles computations of crystal structure, electronic bands, and quantities related to optical and electrical transport properties at the level of density functional theory (DFT). At the third level, correlation effects will be studied within density functional mean field theory (DMFT) to refine the lower level search criteria and identify the most promising systems for further investigation. In the laboratory, synthesis and characterization of the electrical transport and optical properties of these candidate materials and comparison with theoretical predictions will aid in the refinement of design principles and the expansion of the set of transparent conducting materials available for technological applications.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this collaborative proposal was to study a novel paradigm for designing transparent conductor materials - materials which are transparent under visible light, and at the same time good conductors of electricity. The novel paradigm explored involves using electronic correlations that emerge in transition metal oxides to open up a transparency window in the material for visible frequencies of light. PI Birol's role in the team was to perform computational simulations of materials to support and explain the experimental observations, as well as to predict novel materials systems and experimentally feasible way to modify the transparent conducting properties of these materials. Density Functional Theory is the workhorse of computational simulations of the electronic structure of crystalline matter, however, it falls short of reproducing the correlated electronic structure of the transition metal oxides studied in this project. For this reason, a more advanced method that brings together the first principles nature of density functional theory with the ability to capture the electronic correlations was required. DFT+DMFT (Dynamical Mean Field Theory) is the state of the art method that does this, and was employed in this project. 


Initial focus of the work was on perovskite SrVO3, which is a correlated metallic compound the electronic structure of which was already well studied. It was confirmed by DFT+DMFT calculations that the correlated electronic properties observed earlier in Molecular Beam Epitaxy grown films of this material was not a strain induced effect, and is intrinsic to the bulk electronic structure. Systematic DFT+DMFT calculations were used to show that the electronic and optical properties of SrVO3 does not change significantly enough under strain to make it a better correlated metallic transparent conductor. Possible strain tunability of a similar compound, CaVO3, was also evaluated, and it was shown that the oxygen octahedral rotations in CaVO3 - a common crystal structure feature in perovskites, serves as a connection between the crystal and the band structures, makes the electronic correlations more sensitive to small changes in the lattice constant. 


The idea of using a different cation than Vanadium, with a smaller electronegativity to suppress the interband absorption (from Oxygen p states to transition metal d states) was evaluated, and found to be promising. The compounds SrNbO3, which has a similar electronic structure to SrVO3, but with less electronegative Niobium, what shown to not suffer from the optical absorption in the high frequencies that hampers SrVO3's transparency in this frequency range. The lower correlation strength due to the 4d transition metal Nb made this compound reflective to red light, and hence, we proposed this compound as a ultraviolet transparent conductor. Experiments on sputtered films verified the theoretical predictions in the last year of the project period. 
Layered crystal structures, such as the Ruddlesden-Popper series, were put forward as a promising route to dramatically tune the plasma frequency of SrNbO3 and obtain better transparency in all of the visible range. 
In the last year of the project period, so-called double-perovskites (perovskite compounds with two different transition metals on the B site), were studied as transparent conductors. It was shown by first principles calculations that the double perovskite Sr2VNbO6 behaves very differently than both of its parent compounds SrVO3 and SrNbO3. Depending on the cation order (arrangement of V and Nb atoms), this compound either becomes a Mott insulator, or a Hund's metal, which is an exotic type of correlated metal. This happens due to the almost complete transfer of charge between the Nb and V ions, the degree of which is intertwined with both the correlation strength and the cation order. 


This grant was also put to use to provide training for two junior personnel. A starting graduate student was trained on first principles materials science, and a postdoc who was already an expert on DFT was trained in the correlated materials and the DFT+DMFT approach.
